scripts.title: How to Turn Your Electric Bill Into an Optimizable Investment
scripts.hook: Your electric bill went up $23 this month.

segments.audio: One eighty-six ninety-five. That's the new typical Duke Energy bill. Up from one sixty-three.
NC electricity bills up twenty-two percent since twenty twenty. Another increase scheduled for next year.

segments.visual: Split screen: spiky utility bills vs. smooth budget billing line
segments.audio: You can't switch providers. But you can optimize. Budget billing gives you twelve equal payments. Predictable cash flow.
Federal tax credits pay thirty percent of efficiency upgrades. Up to twelve hundred dollars a year. Insulation, windows, HVAC.

segments.visual: Writing on whiteboard: '7-year payback, then $400/year forever'
segments.audio: Spend four thousand on insulation, get twelve hundred back. If it saves four hundred a year, you break even in seven years. Then it's four hundred a year forever.

segments.visual: Three buckets visual: Emergency Fund, Utility Buffer, Retirement
segments.audio: Build a utility buffer. Two to three months of peak bills. Protects your emergency fund and retirement contributions from seasonal spikes.

segments.visual: Jonathan directly to camera, confident expression
segments.audio: Energy costs belong in your financial plan. Optimize them like any other line item. Full strategy linked below.

scripts.title: Energy Efficiency: The Tax-Advantaged Investment Nobody Talks About
scripts.hook: There's a thirty percent return investment most families ignore.

segments.audio: There's a thirty percent return investment most families ignore.

segments.visual: Text overlay: 'Federal Energy Tax Credit: 30% of costs up to $1,200/year'
segments.audio: Federal tax credit. Thirty percent of your home efficiency upgrades. Up to twelve hundred dollars a year through twenty thirty-two.

segments.visual: Whiteboard with calculation: $4,000 insulation - $1,200 credit = $2,800 net cost
segments.audio: Here's the math. You spend four thousand on insulation and air sealing. You get twelve hundred back as a tax credit. Your actual cost is twenty-eight hundred.

segments.visual: Writing on whiteboard: '$400/year savings ÷ $2,800 = 7 year payback'
segments.audio: If those improvements save you four hundred a year on heating and cooling, you break even in seven years. That's a fourteen percent annual return.
After year seven, that four hundred dollars a year is pure savings. Forever. Or until you sell the house, at which point you've increased your home's value.

segments.visual: Split screen: savings account at 0.5% vs. efficiency investment at 14%
segments.audio: Compare that to a savings account paying half a percent. Or even the stock market's historical seven to ten percent. This is a guaranteed return backed by the federal government.

segments.visual: Phone screen showing Duke Energy free audit signup
segments.audio: Start with Duke's free energy assessment. They'll identify the highest-ROI improvements for your specific home. No cost, high-value information.

segments.visual: Jonathan writing 'Tax Credit + Efficiency = Wealth Building' on whiteboard
segments.audio: Then run the numbers. Tax credit plus efficiency equals wealth building. Not just lower bills, but money that stays in your pocket and can be redirected to investments that compound.
Energy efficiency isn't just about being green. It's about keeping more of your money. Full investment breakdown linked below.
